item.title: Connectivity for Telemedicine and Remote Work
item.description:
By: John Shepler The rapid emergence of the Coronavirus pandemic is speeding up existing trends, particularly telemedicine and remote work. Both heavily rely on broadband internet bandwidth. Let’s explore the available connection options. Connecting the User Most remote workers and telemedicine patients connect from home using devices like desktops, smartphones, laptops, or tablets. Home users often prefer cable broadband with speeds of 30 to 100 Mbps, while remote users rely on public WiFi or 4G/5G cellular broadband...

item.title: 80% of employees in Singapore at Dell Technologies are ready to work remotely for an extended period
item.description:
A new study by Dell Technologies called the Remote Work Readiness (RWR) Index explores the attitudes and experiences of Singaporean employees regarding long-term remote work. The study found that while a majority of employees feel prepared for this shift, many believe their employers need to provide more support. The RWR Index surveyed over 7,000 professionals in the Asia Pacific and Japan (APJ) region, with 1,030 participants from Singapore. The study revealed that over 80% of Singaporean employees feel ready for long-term remote work, but many are concerned about the blurring lines between their personal and professional lives...
